When you unravel the history of residential development, readily available surface water was the commanding factor for initial settlement in most locales. Technical advancements then allowed drilled water wells to be common enough that surface water fed by underground water tables or snow runoff (most wetland areas) became more of an annoyance than an asset. Filling them in, the Everglades are probably the most graphic example, and damming surface flow rivers became the name of the game. What made that development feasible was federal infrastructure planning in the form of dams, highways, utilities and communications. Once the federal government had used public money to design infrastructure requirements, it was a simple matter for private industry to lobby state governments for road construction and even cheaper to buy county officials for the purpose of rezoning targeted developments with mixed-use or pure residential zoning, where taxation levels would force farming or ranching operations into a sell position.
 
 Since WW11, the game has became much more sophisticated. The current trend is for developers to secure wetland areas and 'trade' them to the federal government for vast acreage adjacent to the wetlands. Forests? For decades interested parties have used Smokey The Bear to log just about anywhere they want without spending one cent for property purchases. That's a simple matter of having an in-your-pocket politician nudge the proper bureaucrats into declaring an area of timber the market is crying for to be declared a fire hazard, potential bark beetle infestation or endangering residences because people were stupid enough to build on a flood plain in the first place. So much for Steelhead and Salmon runs, spring runoff, fires that rejuvenate forests and all the other normal conditions that renew those resources. 
 
 Face it; the general population and special interests want to use natural resources for their own purposes, and that doesn't include retaining them in a natural state.
